awd_titl_txt: Career Workshops for Teaching Track Faculty
awd_abstract_narration:
The Computing Research Association (CRA) proposes a short series of workshops on professional development (PD) and departmental policies for Computer Science (CS) teaching faculty. CS departments nationwide are experiencing significant increases in undergraduate majors and undergraduate course enrollments, resulting in an increased reliance on teaching faculty positions. For many PhD producing departments, positions such as these with academic rank and an expectation of scholarship are new, and the departments are still defining their role and career path opportunities. At the same time, new PhDs, current teaching faculty, and individuals considering a career change seek information about such positions.

The series of workshops will include a 1-day PD Workshop for current teaching faculty and 2 half-day Academic Landscape Workshops for graduating PhD students, post-docs and industry professionals considering an academic position. The PD Workshop will be held in conjunction with the SIGCSE 2020 Conference. The workshop will fill a crucial need as departments have limited experience on how to mentor, evaluate, and promote teaching faculty. The workshop will highlight ways to be successful in advancing one's career, build understanding of expectations and opportunities, and provide ways to connect teaching faculty with each other. The Academic Landscape Workshops are  designed for those considering teaching faculty positions and  will be held in conjunction with conferences attended by a diverse range of participants.  The workshops  will introduce participants to the different academic teaching faculty careers, increase awareness of the landscape of academic career options in PhD granting departments, and highlight exemplars of successful career paths. They will also discuss such topics as how to best prepare, how to interview, and how to negotiate offers for teaching faculty positions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Computer Science (CS) departments have experienced significant increases in the number of undergraduate majors as well as well as in the number of non-majors taking CS courses.   To manage these increases, many PhD-granting departments hire academic-rank teaching faculty. The project developed, organized, and facilitated a series of workshops to inform future and current teaching faculty of career options and expectations, share and advance best practices, build a community and a network of teaching faculty, and empower teaching faculty so they will have a successful career.

For teaching faculty, four workshops were held in conjunction with the annual ACM SIGCSE conference (in 2020, 2021, 2022 and 2023). The workshops focused on professional development and career planning. They filled a crucial need as many Ph.D. granting departments have limited experience on how to mentor, evaluate, and promote teaching faculty.  Workshop sessions included guidance and options on productive involvement in departmental and research activities, different forms of scholarship and leadership activities to pursue, and best practices for success, promotion, and advancement.

For graduate students, post-docs and people in industry interested in teaching careers, two workshops were held in conjunction with the ACM Federated Computing Research Conference (FCRC) in 2018 and 2023. The goal of the workshops was to increase awareness of the broad landscape of academic teaching-focused career options. Workshop session topics included identifying open positions matching one's interests, preparing a successful application, navigating the interview process, and starting a teaching career.

Intellectual Merit. For many departments, teaching faculty positions with academic rank and an expectation of scholarship are new, and departments are still defining their role and career path opportunities. At the same time, new PhDs, current teaching faculty, and individuals considering a career change seek information about such positions.  The workshops contributed to (i) raising the awareness of teaching faculty positions as a career option and (ii) developing best practices supporting professional development of teaching faculty and making evidence-based recommendations for departmental leaders.

Broader Impact. Hiring and retaining teaching track faculty is crucial for successfully managing enrollment increases.  The Academic Landscape workshops have the potential to contribute to retaining PhDs in academia and preparing a future workforce in computing fields. The Professional Development workshops contribute to retention of teaching faculty by highlighting models of a successful career.  Both workshops can have a lasting impact on the participants. Meeting other teaching-focused faculty, teaching faculty building a network of peers,  and starting new collaborations are valuable to all teaching faculty, especially in environments where finding an advocate or a truly supportive mentor is a challenge.

The workshops were organized by CRA-E, CRA's  Education Committee. More information about the workshops can be found at https://cra.org/crae/activities/.
